awd_titl_txt: Examining the correlated molecular mechanisms of self and heterospecific pollen-pistil recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
Flowering plants display their charismatic flowers open and ready for pollinators or wind to bring pollen for reproduction. Determining how plants successfully reproduce requires understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying how female reproductive organs (pistils) recognize and accept high quality pollen while rejecting low quality pollen. The recognition between pistils and pollen is significant for two important mate choices in plants - distinguishing between self-pollen and non-self-pollen as well as between pollen from the same species and pollen from different species. This research investigates the molecular mechanisms underlying self-pollen reject and foreign-species pollen rejection in Phlox drummondii, a native Texas wildflower. In this species there is extensive natural variation in the ability of pistils to recognize and reject self and foreign pollen and the variation in these two recognition systems is highly correlated across individuals. This research involves a detailed genetic investigation of molecular mechanisms causing pollen-pistil recognition and the causes of the correlation between incompatibilities. Specifically, this research combines quantitative genetic dissection of variation in incompatibilities, with genome-wide gene expression analyses, and an artificial selection experiment to discover new mechanisms of pollen-pistil interactions in a species that has evolved self and foreign incompatibly independently of those found in model plant systems. This research will be complemented by outreach activities associated with the local natural history museum. The scientists will create educational activities for elementary and high school students, provide teacher professional development workshops about floral diversity, and organize public lectures on plant science. 

This project investigates the long-standing hypothesis that self and heterospecific pollen-pistil incompatibility systems are mechanistically linked by dissecting the molecular basis of variation in incompatibility within a non-model wildflower species. Specifically, this research will determine if self and heterospecific recognition share genetic mechanisms, if the breakdown of self and heterospecific incompatibility involves multiple genes including genes outside the self-identity locus, and if the correlation between self and heterospecific incompatibility could constrain the evolution of pollen-pistil recognition. To accomplish these goals, this research will determine the molecular mechanisms underlying incompatibly through whole-genome gene expression analyses, characterize the genetic architecture of the breakdown of self and heterospecific pollen recognition through genetic mapping experiments, and quantify the genetic constraint imposed by the correlation between incompatibilities using an artificial selection experiment. This integrative research will test specific hypotheses about the genetic basis of incompatibly in plants while discovering new mechanisms of pollen-pistil recognition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant investigates the interactions between pollen and pistils during sexual reproduction in plants. Specifically, our work aims to understand the mechanisms plants use to identify and reject pollen from themselves and from plants of a different species.

 A major goal of our work was to discover new mechanisms of pollen-pistil interactions in under-studied plant species. We made significant accomplishments toward this goal through our identification of the pistil-expressed gene in the S-locus of Phlox. The S-locus refers to the multi-genic, non-recombining region of the genome that contains the pollen-expressed and pistil-expressed genes necessary for self-pollen recognition. These loci have evolved independently many times throughout flowering plant evolution and share convergent function. We know the genetic basis underlying few of them. For the first time in over a decade, we have identified a gene in an S-locus and characterized a novel mechanism for self-recognition. Our findings represent a huge breakthrough in our understanding of self-incompatibility specifically and cell-cell communication mechanisms more broadly.  

 A second goal of our work was to characterize the genetic architecture of the breakdown of self and heterospecific pollen recognition within a species. Using multiple genetic mapping populations, we discovered that variation in incompatibility is highly heritable and caused by multiple loci segregating variation that collectively contribute to compatibility. Furthermore, we discovered that some, but not all, of this variation in compatibility is associated with genetic variation at the S-locus specifically.

 The final major goal of our work was to quantify the genetic correlation between self and heterospecific incompatibility. This grant funded an enormous artificial selection experiment to investigate this aim. We confirmed that variation in pollen-pistil incompatibility is due to genetic variation and can respond rapidly to selection. Interestingly, self-incompatibility seems to show a stronger response to selection compared to heterospecific incompatibility. Importantly, we discovered that variation in two forms of pollen-recognition is genetically independent and unlinked. In other words, self- and heterospecific-incompatibility respond independently to selection and there is ample variation for them to evolve. Our results suggest that the natural correlations we find between these two incompatibilities in wild populations is not due to shared genetic mechanisms but instead due to parallel selection.

 Thus far our work has resulted in two publications with three more manuscripts in preparation that detail the research described above. One publication used controlled greenhouse experiments and molecular data to quantify variation in autonomous self-fertilization in a self-compatible Phlox species. This work surveyed individuals from across the range of a Phlox species and concluded that, despite strong hypotheses to the contrary, individuals sympatric with closely related species did not have higher rates of autonomous selfing compared to allopatric individuals. A second paper provides a detailed mechanistic investigation of how biomechanical interactions between pollen and pistils from different Phlox species can result in strong and asymmetric incompatibilities. It reveals that small pollen from short-styled plants lack the resources to grow down long styles and thus cannot fertilize the ovule. These two publications were in support of the larger theme of our research to understand mechanisms through which plants have evolved pollen-choice.

 The broader impacts of this project have included public education activities, training of undergraduate, graduate, and post-graduate scientists, and generating publicly available educational science material about plant reproduction and speciation. Specifically, this grant has supported the careers of three postdoctoral researchers, two of whom have gone on to secure tenure-track faculty positions and the third secured his dream job of leading education and research resources at the Harvard Forest. This grant has supported the careers of one graduate student and post-baccalaureate researchers as well as 7 undergraduate researchers including two summers of REU support. Eight of these participants identify as female or non-binary and five identify as under-represented non-white minorities in our field. The people supported by this award have worked to disseminate the knowledge and broader importance of science by engagement with the Arnold Arboretum Young Scientist program that brings inner-city kids into nature to teach them about plants and ecosystems, participation in teacher training and professional development programs for Boston-area science teachers, and hosting workshops and retreats for Boston-area high school science teachers. Our work has engaged more broadly with the public through our scientists starting the very popular Let’s Botanize plant science outreach channel on TikTok and Instagram, teaching an outreach classe on plant-pollinator interactions and floral diversity for the Arnold Arboretum YouTube Channel, and producing an educational video with “Science in Real Life” about plant sexual reproduction and speciation. Finally, the PI of this grant and many of the participants are active members of both our department and the Arnold Arboretum committee for Diversity, Inclusion, and Belonging. Through these efforts we have work to build community and foster conversations about issues and ideas regarding diversity of thought in the plant sciences.
